phrasebook.title: Star in a Box

about.title: About
about.content:
Star in a Box allows you to explore one of the most enigmatic tools in astronomy - the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram.

When you first open the box you start with a star with the same mass as the Sun but you can change this to a different mass at any time. The tracks that you see on the graph (on the left) map the lifecycle of the star. You can play the animation of the star moving around the diagram, and see how its brightness, size, surface temperature, and mass change in the panels on the right.

Stars can take billions of years to go through their lives with the dramatic events taking place in relatively short periods of time. In the animation we speed up time when the star is not really changing much and slow things down for the dramatic phases of the star's life.

Keyboard controls:

%CONTROLLIST%

Acknowledgments

Design & Development: Jon Yardley, Stuart Lowe, Edward Gomez, Haley Gomez & Chris North

Supported by LCOGT & Cardiff University

Based on the stellar evolution research of Jarrod Hurley, Onno Pols, and Christopher Tout

intro.title: Welcome!
intro.content:
You are now the proud owner of Star In A Box.

Inside this box you can animate the different stages in a star's life and see how its brightness, size, and mass change with time.

Once you've opened the box just click the play button to start animating.

phrasebook.preparing:
Your star is being prepared.
Please wait...

buttons.reset: Back to the start of your star's life

content.m0_2:
0.2 Times The Mass of The Sun

Main Sequence

Stars around or less than half the mass of the Sun start off as low mass Main Sequence stars. Here, they are in very stable states where they fuse hydrogen atoms into helium as a source of energy.

Red Giant

When the core of the star runs out of hydrogen to fuse into helium, the outer layers of the star begin to swell and the surface temperature of the star cools, the star also changes appearance to become redder. Since stars of this mass are too small to initiate helium fusing in the core, the star burns out all of its hydrogen supply, leaving the helium core behind, as what is known as a 'Helium White Dwarf'.
content.m0_65:
0.65 Times The Mass of The Sun

Main Sequence

Stars around or less than half the mass of the Sun start off as low mass Main Sequence stars. Here, they are in very stable states where they fuse hydrogen atoms into helium as a source of energy.

Red Giant

When the core of the star runs out of hydrogen to fuse into helium, the outer layers of the star begin to swell and the surface temperature of the star cools, the star also changes appearance to become redder. Since stars of this mass are too small to initiate helium fusing in the core, the star burns out all of its hydrogen supply, leaving the helium core behind, as what is known as a 'Helium White Dwarf'.
content.m1:
Stars With The Mass of The Sun

Main Sequence

The main sequence stage is the longest inhabited stage by a star. Here the star remains stable for millions to billions of years, fusing hydrogen atoms into helium atoms as fuel.

Red Giant

When all of the hydrogen in the core turns into helium, the outer layers of the star begin to swell and become redder as they do in stars of around 0.2-0.65 times the mass of the Sun. However, for stars the same mass as the Sun and up to 8 times the mass of the Sun, the core becomes hot enough to fuse helium into heavier elements such as carbon and oxygen. However they still aren't heavy enough to fuse carbon and oxygen into heavier elements in the core.

White Dwarf

Eventually the hydrogen and helium layers of the star fade away leaving a 'White Dwarf' similar to low mass stars.
content.m2:
2 Times The Mass of The Sun

Main Sequence

The main sequence stage is the longest inhabited stage by a star. Here the star remains stable for millions to billions of years, fusing hydrogen atoms into helium atoms as fuel.

Red Giant

When all of the hydrogen in the core turns into helium, the outer layers of the star begin to swell and become redder as they do in stars of around 0.2-0.65 times the mass of the Sun. However, for stars the same mass as the Sun and up to 8 times the mass of the Sun, the core becomes hot enough to fuse helium into heavier elements such as carbon and oxygen. However they still aren't heavy enough to fuse carbon and oxygen into heavier elements in the core. Eventually the hydrogen and helium layers of the star fade away leaving a 'Carbon/Oxygen White Dwarf' similar to low mass stars.
content.m4:
4 Times The Mass of The Sun

Main Sequence

The main sequence stage is the longest inhabited stage by a star. Here the star remains stable for millions to billions of years, fusing hydrogen atoms into helium atoms as fuel.

Red Giant

When all of the hydrogen in the core turns into helium, the outer layers of the star begin to swell and become redder as they do in stars of around 0.2-0.65 times the mass of the Sun. However, for stars the same mass as the Sun and up to 8 times the mass of the Sun, the core becomes hot enough to fuse helium into heavier elements such as carbon and oxygen. However they still aren't heavy enough to fuse carbon and oxygen into heavier elements in the core. Eventually the hydrogen and helium layers of the star fade away leaving a 'Carbon/Oxygen White Dwarf' similar to low mass stars.
content.m6:
6 Times The Mass of The Sun

Main Sequence

The main sequence stage is the longest inhabited stage by a star. Here the star remains stable for millions to billions of years, fusing hydrogen atoms into helium atoms as fuel.

Red Giant

When all of the hydrogen in the core turns into helium, the outer layers of the star begin to swell and become redder as they do in stars of around 0.2-0.65 times the mass of the Sun. However, for stars the same mass as the Sun and up to 8 times the mass of the Sun, the core becomes hot enough to fuse helium into heavier elements such as carbon and oxygen. However they still aren't heavy enough to fuse carbon and oxygen into heavier elements in the core. Eventually the hydrogen and helium layers of the star fade away leaving a 'Carbon/Oxygen White Dwarf' similar to low mass stars.
content.m10:
10 Times The Mass of The Sun

Main Sequence

The main sequence stage is the longest inhabited stage by a star. Here the star remains stable for millions of years, fusing hydrogen atoms into helium atoms as fuel.

Red Giant

When all of the hydrogen in the core turns into helium, the outer layers of the star begin to swell and become redder as they do in stars of around 1-6 times the mass of the Sun. However, for stars the same mass as the Sun and heavier, the core becomes hot enough to fuse helium into heavier elements such as carbon and oxygen. Stars 10 to 20 times the mass of the Sun will be able to initiate fusing of atoms like oxygen and carbon in the core. Eventually the star will have an onion like structure, with different elements in different layers, such as hydrogen, helium, carbon, oxygen and neon, but will stop at iron. Once fusion stops at Iron, there is no more nuclear reactions to stop the core from collapsing, upon doing so a supernova takes place, and all that is left is a Neutron star.
content.m20:
20 Times The Mass of The Sun

Main Sequence

The main sequence stage is the longest inhabited stage by a star. Here the star remains stable for millions of years, fusing hydrogen atoms into helium atoms as fuel.

Red Giant

When all of the hydrogen in the core turns into helium, the outer layers of the star begin to swell and become redder as they do in stars of around 1-6 times the mass of the Sun. However, for stars the same mass as the Sun and heavier, the core becomes hot enough to fuse helium into heavier elements such as carbon and oxygen. Stars 10 to 20 times the mass of the Sun will be able to initiate fusing of atoms like oxygen and carbon in the core. Eventually the star will have an onion like structure, with different elements in different layers, such as hydrogen, helium, carbon, oxygen and neon, but will stop at iron. Once fusion stops at Iron, there is no more nuclear reactions to stop the core from collapsing, upon doing so a supernova takes place, and all that is left is a Neutron star.
content.m30:
30 Times The Mass of The Sun

Main Sequence

The main sequence stage is the longest inhabited stage by a star. Here the star remains stable for millions of years, fusing hydrogen atoms into helium atoms as fuel.

Red Giant

When all of the hydrogen in the core turns into helium, the outer layers of the star begin to swell and become redder as they do in stars of around 1-6 times the mass of the Sun. Stars of 30 times the Sun, and even heavier will be able to initiate fusing of much heavier elements in the core, such as helium, carbon, oxygen and neon.

Blue Giant

Stars this heavy will have very strong stellar winds, which will blow away the outer layers of the star leaving the hotter interior on show. Due to the much hotter surface temperature the star will appear as a blue giant. Eventually the core will collapse, with a large supernova, however left over will be a black hole, an object with such a strong gravitational field, not even light can escape (hence it being called 'Black').
content.m40:
40 Times The Mass of The Sun

Main Sequence

The main sequence stage is the longest inhabited stage by a star. Here the star remains stable for millions of years, fusing hydrogen atoms into helium atoms as fuel.

Red Giant

When all of the hydrogen in the core turns into helium, the outer layers of the star begin to swell and become redder as they do in stars of around 1-6 times the mass of the Sun. Stars of 30 times the Sun, and even heavier will be able to initiate fusing of much heavier elements in the core, such as helium, carbon, oxygen and neon.

Blue Giant

Stars this heavy will have very strong stellar winds, which will blow away the outer layers of the star leaving the hotter interior on show. Due to the much hotter surface temperature the star will appear as a blue giant. Eventually the core will collapse, with a large supernova, however left over will be a black hole, an object with such a strong gravitational field, not even light can escape (hence it being called 'Black').

tutorial: Welcome! At the moment you have a 1 solar mass star but you can change that here if you want to.
This is your star at the start of its life. The dashed line shows how the star's brightness and temperature will change over its life.
Click the play button when you're ready to start animating your star.

captions.rScales:
Mass

This shows how the mass of your star varies over its life. Stars lose mass gradually by converting hydrogen into helium and heavier elements. They can also lose mass through winds blowing off their surface and at dramatic moments in their lives.

Stars are massive so, rather than measure this in kilograms, we measure this in comparison to our Sun which has 1 Solar Mass - which is about 2 million million million million million kg!
captions.rStopwatch:
Stages in your star's life

This stopwatch shows the relative time the star spends in each stage of its life. In the animation we speed up time when the star is not really changing much and slow things down for the dramatic phases of the star's life.
captions.rlum:
Brightness

How the brightness of your star changes compared to the current brightness of our Sun (which has a value of 1 in this light meter).

This light meter also changes colour to match your star.
captions.thermometer:
Surface Temperature

How the surface temperature of your star changes with time. The temperatures are given in Kelvin which is usually abbreviated to K. Remember that:

0°C = 273 K
captions.rCanvas:
Size

How your star changes in size and colour, compared to the current conditions of the Sun.
